title: First Report of Stemphylium lycopersici Causing Gray Leaf Spot on Physali (Physalis alkekengi) in China

Li; E-mail Address: [email protected]Laboratory of Genetic Breeding in Tomato, Key Laboratory of Biology and Genetic Improvement of Horticultural Crops (Northeast Region), College of Horticulture and Landscape Architecture, Northeast Agricultural University, Xiangfang District Harbin 150030, ChinaAffiliationsAuthors and Affiliations Huanhuan Yang Yue Li Yuqing He Yaoguang Sun Jingbin Jiang Tingting Zhao He Zhang Xiangyang Xu † Jingfu Li † Laboratory of Genetic Breeding in Tomato, Key Laboratory of Biology and Genetic Improvement of Horticultural Crops (Northeast Region), College of Horticulture and Landscape Architecture, Northeast Agricultural University, Xiangfang District Harbin 150030, China Published Online:18 Aug 2020https://doi.org/10.1094/PDIS-10-19-2231-PDNAboutSectionsSupplemental ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack Citations ShareShare onFacebookTwitterLinked InRedditEmailWechat During the July 2017 to 2018 growing seasons, a disease of physali observed in Bin County, Heilongjiang Province, China, affected more than 65% of plants in seven greenhouses. Symptoms of infected leaves in the early stages exhibited brownish-black specks that later expanded into necrotic lesions. Subsequently, rapid wilting of the foliage and complete defoliation took place as the disease developed further. Lesions ranged from 2 to 8 mm in diameter. A putative fungal pathogen was isolated from infected leaves. Small pieces of infected leaves (5 × 5 mm) were surface sterilized for 1 min in 0.5% NaOCl, 75% ethanol for 5 s, and rinsed twice with sterilized distilled water. The isolates were grown on potato dextrose agar (PDA) with a 12-h photoperiod at 28°C for 5 to 10 days. Gray to light brown colonies were obtained from the samples on PDA. Colonies had hyaline, septate hyphae with conidia that were oblong with a conical apex, a bluntly rounded base, constricted at three major transverse septa, pale to mid brown in color, mostly 50 to 81 μm long and 15 to 28 μm wide. The isolates were identified morphologically as Stemphylium sp. in Physalis alkekengi (Woudenberg et al. 2017). The internal transcribed spacer region of rDNA was amplified with primers ITS1/ITS4, and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GPD) was amplified with primers GPD-F/R for the PCR amplification of genomic DNA. Fragments of approximately 650 and 850 bp were generated, respectively. All sequences were submitted to GenBank (accession nos. MN515100 and MN515101). These sequences were 99% identical to Stemphylium lycopersici (KR911814) (Hong et al. 2012). Woudenberg et al. (2017) proposed CBS 122639 (GenBank accession no. KU850611) as the ex-neotype of S. lycopersici, and KU850611 (524 bp) showed 100% identity with our GenBank accession numbers MN515100 (568 bp) and MN515101 (564 bp). Sequences of the portion of GPD gene, accession numbers MN595210 and MN595211, showed 99% identity with S. lycopersici isolate from tomato (KT957743.1) (Sun et al. 2016). To complete Koch's postulates, five isolates were grown on PDA and washed of spores, and a conidial suspension (1 × 105 spores/ml) was prepared. To inoculate plants, the suspension was sprayed onto leaves. In pathogenicity tests, each treatment was inoculated onto five plants, and another five control plants were sprayed with sterilized water. All plants were grown in a greenhouse at 28°C, relative humidity >85% and 12-h/day light cycle. After 3 days water-soaked lesions developed, and depressed lesions appeared after 5 days, whereas control plants showed no symptoms. Finally, S. lycopersici was reisolated from the leaf lesions. To our knowledge, this is the first record of S. lycopersici causing gray leaf spot of physali in China.The author(s) declare no conflict of interest.References:Hong, S. K., et al. 2012.
